snippet: The new boom in American prisons is happening in mostly white, rural and politically conservative areas....
abstract: The Upshot; analysis by The New York Times finds that counties in United States with fewer than 100,000 people are increasingly resorting to lengthy prison sentences even as bipartisan national  campaign to reduce mass incarceration has resulted in sharp declines in new inmates in larger cities; people in small counties like Dearborn County, Ind, are 50 percent more likely to go to prison than those in larger counties, trend that has been driven in part by growing heroin epidemic.

byline.original: By JOSH KELLER and ADAM PEARCE

lead_paragraph: The new boom in American prisons is happening in mostly white, rural and politically conservative areas.

headline.print_headline: Rural Divide on Jail Time: Less Leniency
headline.main: This small Indiana county sends more people to prison than San Francisco and Durham, N.C., combined. Why?
